Recipe.title: Fried Rice
Recipe.Description:
When Ransom was a Scout Master for 11-year-olds, he wanted to make a special Dutch oven meal for their first campout. He went through a bunch of cookbooks and came up with a recipe similar to this one, which he used as a main course.
Later, after he was married, he was given a Wok, so he modified that recipe to this one for use as a side-dish.

section.instruction: Slice the Chinese Cabbage as thinly as possible. (Goal is to have 1-2 Cups.)
Slice the Scallions into ½"e2; pieces.
Cut Chicken into ¼" chunks, thoroughly cook, then set aside.
In a large wok or pot, combine Rice and Oil.
Cook the mixture on medium-high heat, stirring frequently, until Rice begins to brown. (10-15 minutes)
Add Chicken and vegetables, then stir well.
Dig as large of a hole as possible in the center of the Rice, all the way to the bottom, pushing the Rice to the outside edges of the wok or pot.
Break the Eggs into the hole, then stir the Eggs (not the Rice) until the Eggs are cooked and shredded.
Stir entire mixture together, then add Soy Sauce.

Notes.note:
For best results, cook the Rice the day before, then let it sit in the refrigerator overnight.
If that is not possible, cook the Rice then spread it out to cool on a cookie sheet or butcher paper.
A cheese grater is ideal for "coarsely shredding" the Carrots.

Modifications.modification: Instead of Chicken, you can use other meats, such as Ham (which doesn't need to be precooked) or Beef. You could also use a mixture of several meats, or even leave the meat completely out.
If you add extra meat, this can be treated as a main course instead of just a side-dish. (With only half as many servings.)
For a slightly milder flavor, you can substitute Onions for Scallions. If so, you should precook the Onions with the meat.
For a slightly different flavor, substitute the green leaves from Celery for the Chinese Cabbage.
If desired, you can add other vegetables, such as Corn or Baby Corn, Sliced Mushrooms, Water Chestnuts, Peas, etc.
